Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and notes scattered around me, trying to finalize the outline for tomorrow’s mentoring session. My mentees were counting on me to guide them through the last steps before their big project deadline, and I wanted to make sure I covered every detail. Just as I was reviewing my slides, my younger brother plopped down beside me, grinning. “We’re talking about what to do this weekend—come help us decide!” My mom called from the living room, “We want everyone’s input!”

I glanced at the clock. If I joined them now, I’d lose precious time to prepare, and I knew my mentees needed me to be at my best. But my family expected me to be present, to laugh and share ideas, to be a good sister. The voices from the living room grew louder, and my brother nudged me, eyes hopeful. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of family and the responsibility of mentorship. I felt the pressure mounting, the weight of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions, and I sat frozen, unable to choose.
